page.title: 15St. Agnes: Cornish language
page.content: The Cornish language is no longer confined to snatches of dialect, and place names. Today there are more people with a knowledge of the language who can read, write and speak it than at any time during the past 250 years. A language revival was begun by some Cornish scholars at the beginning of this century. The language is continuing today with a fair degree of success. But outside Cornwall it is not generally known that there IS a Cornish language. Instead there remain vague folk memories of the "differentness" of the Cornish people. Cornish is one of six Celtic languages that survive today. The Tonkin family of Trevaunance used as their motto "Kenz of tra, Tonkin ouna Dev Mahtern yn" - "Tonkin, above all things, Fear God and the King." This was known as Middle Cornish.
